Authors:
Roël Dire HOUDANON, Brendan FURNEAUX, Nourou Soulemane
YOROU, Martin Karl RYBERG
Title:
Molecular community phylogeny and affiliation of tropical
African ectomycorrhizal fungi
Keywords:
West Africa, Ectomycorrhizal fungi, phylogeny, community
phylogenetics
Abstract:
Ectomycorrhizal fungi form a mutualistic symbiosis with
plant roots that is key for nutrient cycling in many ecosystems. Here we
use phylogenies of fungal families based on the LSU region of the rDNA
and RPB2 to infer the evolutionary relations between species found in
the “Ouémé Supérieur” forest reserve (OSRF) in Benin (West Africa) to
investigate the structure of the underlying ectomycorrhizal community.
We tested if the species are closer to other tropical African species
than to species from other regions. A total of 9 species in Amanitaceae,
3 in Boletaceae, 1 in Cantharellaceae, 1 in Cortinarius, 2 in
Inocybaceae, 20 in Russulaceae and 3 in Sclerodermataceae were found.
Some of the species could be inferred to be associated with previously
described taxa: Amanita pseudovaginata, Amanita loosii, Amanita
congolensis, Amanita aff. masasiensis, Imperator luteocupreus,
Cantharellus addaiensis, Russula oleifera, Lactifluus luteopus,
Lactifluus nonpiscis and Lactarius saponaceus, while the majority could
not. Our analyses of the different families show that the species from
the community of ectomycorrhizal fungi in OSRF are phylogenetically more
distant from each other than expected by chance, but are generally found
in clades dominated by tropical African, or at least tropical species.
Specifically, our results suggest that Sub-Saharian African species of
Amanita are phylogenetically clustered. Similar clustering patterns are
observed for Cantharellus, Inocybeaceae, Cortinarius and Russulaceae.
Only Sclerodermataceae species display an over-dispersed pattern. This
indicates that the transition between tropical and temperate areas is
relatively rare (compared to speciation events) and that dispersal
limitations may restrict continental species pools or that adaptations
to local habitats and hosts restrict distributions. That the species
assemblage is over-dispersed at the community level may indicate
competitive exclusion, or large-scale biogeographic processes based on
allopatric speciation and dispersal limits.
